service_description:
For children 6 weeks to 3 years. Provides school readiness; family advocacy; and educational, health, nutritional, social and other services.  Home-based education program also available. Multiple locations; call for more information.

Facilities closed for coronavirus until further notice. Main office closed. All
mail/email will be answered upon re-opening. Albina Head Start and Early Head Start
Center Based services will continue remotely through the planned school year, May 7th
for Head Start and June 25th for Early Head Start. We will be in touch soon with
information on how to pick up any personal items your child may have in the classroom.
Home Based services (home visits) will continue remotely through May 21st for Head
Start and August 14th for Early Head Start.

Free preschool for qualifying families with children 3-5 that provides school readiness;
family advocacy; and educational, health, nutritional, social and other services.
hours: Office hours: 8:30 a.m.-5 p.m. Mon.-Fri. Classroom hours: 7 a.m.-4:30 p.m.

service_description: Shelter, supportive services for homeless, runaway and at-risk youths ages 12 to 20. Offers food and basic needs assistance, case management, referrals to resources. 30-day shelter program.
hours: Drop-in services hours: 9a.m.-12p.m. and 4p.m.-8p.m. 7 days a week.

service_description: Foster care and adoption services, homeless youths shelter program and all-options counseling for pregnant women.

Facilitates access to knowledgeable providers for transgender and genderqueer children,
youths, adults and their families. Services include counseling, assessments and planning for
medical transition, psychological assessments, support groups, acupuncture and massage,
free clothing closet for clients, scholarship for gender-related care not covered by insurance.

Central City Concern is temporarily suspending operations of its Urgent Care Clinic at the Bud Clark Center Resource Center. Stay tuned for details.

Community-based outpatient treatment program for Latino youth ages 12-21 who are
struggling with addiction, including alcohol. Counseling and case management services
available.

Facilities closed for coronavirus until further notice. Call your counselor directly.

Leave a voice message at 503-367-4730, but it may take a while for someone to respond.

Transitional housing services for male and female veterans. Access program by attending orientation held every Mon. 10 a.m. Tues. at the Employment Access Center. Call 503-525-8483 for assistance with housing. Call 971-361-7888 for a medical appointment. Call 971-361-7888 for a recovery services appointment. Call the office for help with finding a job, job training and with questions or for more info.

Child advocacy center specializing in medical assessments and forensic interviews for kids who’ve experienced abuse, neglect, drug exposure. Family support services offered. Referrals accepted from DHS/Law enforcement, primary care providers, parents, and any concerned school staff.
Helps military veterans and their families get the benefits they’ve earned. No walk ins. Call to make an appointment.
hours: Hours: 7 a.m.-12 p.m. and 1 p.m.-5 p.m. Mon.-Thurs.

service_description:
Any student who is unsheltered, couch surfing or living in an insecure housing situation is eligible for homeless student services including transportation to school district of origin when feasible.

Free private, nonprofit Pre-K to eighth grade school for children whose families are homeless, in housing transition or children at risk of school failure. Call for information. Enroll over the phone.

Call for current appointment availability. Individual counseling services for children and youths who have witnessed family violence. Individual counseling for teens 14 to 18 who have experienced teen dating violence. Call to schedule intake appt. Children and youths under 14 must have a non-offending parent or guardian willing to receive some parental education.

listing: Ecumenical Ministries, Russian Oregon Social Services
service_description: Provides stable housing and ongoing support for unaccompanied students experiencing homelessness, so they can focus on completing their secondary education. Call for more information or talk to the school district homeless liaison for referral. Serves youths in Gresham-Barlow and Washington, Clackamas and Lincoln County school districts

Dual diagnosis residential substance use treatment for male-identified clients ages 13-18.
Alternative high school on site.
hours: Walk-in hours: 8 a.m.-5:30 p.m. Mon.-Fri. Access center hours: 8 a.m.-5 p.m. Mon.-Fri., 8 a.m.-1 p.m. Sat.

service_description: Support for veterans and their families including food, clothing, and shelter or housing. Call for more info.
Community supports and services.  Go onto their website and list the need that you have if you live in Sandy.
Meals, place to relax and shower facilities.
Resource center helping youths ages 12-24 find housing, education, employment, health referrals, clothes, food. Place to relax. Free meal. No religious doctrines. Laundry and shower facilities.
hours:
Hours: 3 p.m.-5 p.m. & 6 p.m.-8 p.m. 
Mon. & Wed. 
2 p.m.-5 p.m. Tues.

service_description: Services and support for teen parents and their partners who are younger than 22, including case management, information and recreation. Call for screening/referral. Resource closet of childrens items and diapers available by appt.

Street Light provides 30 short-term shelter beds and Porch Light provides 30 long-term beds for homeless youths, ages 15-23. Emergency shelter to those new to the streets or in immediate need of shelter available at 8:45 p.m. Beds distributed on first-come, first-served basis nightly. Street Light requires a reservation from the case manager.
hours:
Street Light hours: 9 p.m.-8:45 a.m. Mon.-Sun. 
Porch Light hours: 8:45 p.m.-8:45 a.m. Mon.-Sun.

service_description: First aid and hygiene supplies, resource information, and crisis information available. Nightly street outreach program focuses on providing street-based information, referral and crisis intervention services directly to street-dependent youths ages 15-24.
hours: On the street from 6-9 p.m. every night

service_description: Short-term shelter and case management for ages 9-17 (12 beds available). Family counseling for ages 13-17.
hours: 24-hour access for runaways. After 8 p.m. speak to crisis intake specialist.

service_description: 16-24 years old experiencing homelessness. Screenings 365 days a year.  Call between 8 a.m.-6 p.m. to talk to a screener.  After 5 pm. go to Porch Light Crisis Shelter 1635 SW Alder St., at 8:45 p.m. for a safe place to stay. Porch Light phone: 503-380-7200.  Access center is appointment only.  Start lining up at Porch Light at 8:45 pm.
hours: Screeners available hours: 9 a.m.-5 p.m. Mon.-Sun.

service_description: Staffed by people trained in military culture to confidentially assist in sorting through issues like family, anger, substance abuse, post-traumatic, and  suicide.  We can direct callers to other resources as necessary.
Peer-to-peer crisis and help line for teens. Support for youths regarding anything bothering you. No problem too big or small.
hours: Line answered 24/7. Staffed by teens 4-10 p.m. Texting available 4-10 p.m. Text teen2teen to 839863. Chat online.

service_description: By appointment only. Provides personalized care by matching needs with resources, including infant and childrens items, cleaning and personal hygiene, furniture and household goods. Also offers classes, workshops, vocational support.

listing: Multnomah County Child Care Resource & Referral
service_description: Assistance for qualifying families to pay for child care services through the Community Child Care Initiative (CCI) program. Parents searching for child care, call 211.
hours:
Hours: Phone hours: 8 a.m.-4:30 p.m. Mon.-Fri.
Office hours Tues. and Thurs 8:30am - 4:00pm

service_description:
Assists veterans and their dependents with obtaining and understanding all benefits available to them under state and federal laws. The office works with the county agencies, the Oregon and U.S. Departments of Veterans Affairs. Various locations. Call for appt. See website for provider/self referral form.

Phone assistance only. Call and leave message. Call for appt. No walk ins. Physical location is closed.

Early intervention and early childhood special education services to children, birth to age 5. Services are individually designed to address the special needs of young children with developmental delays or disabilities free of charge.
Groups, outings, life skills training, suicide prevention.
Youth Residential Treatment: Holistic and culturally specific outpatient and advocacy services. Call for intake.
Child and Family Program: Child and family services include Mental Health assessments, services and counseling.

Culturally specific wraparound and educational advocacy, tutoring and career skills development for Native-American youths. Domestic violence prevention and intervention services. Access to homeless youth services, including shelter and basic needs for all youths ages 16-24.
Alternative School, transitional housing, day services, job-readiness training for youths ages 16-24. Drop-in day services for youths ages 16-24.
hours:
Meal hours: 9-10 a.m., 1-2 p.m., 5-6 p.m. Mon.-Fri., 1-2 p.m., 5-6 p.m. Sat. 
Open hours: 1-6 p.m. Mon., Wed., Sat.

service_description: 24/7 for youth ages 9-17; Monday-Friday 10am-6pm for youth ages 18-24. Emergency shelter for youth ages 9-17, case management, mentorship and family mediation; case management and wraparound services for youth ages 18-24, including education and employment.

Provides free early intervention and early childhood special education services to children from birth to age 5 who have developmental delays or disabilities, including speech and language, motor, behavioral, social skills, learning, self-help, vision, and hearing.

Assists transgender/gender non-conforming people in establishing Outside In as primary care location, initiate hormone therapy and manage their health as they physically transition. The ID Project helps change their legal documentation through the courts or DMV. Call for more information and appt. availability.
hours: Hours: Mon.-Thurs. 8:30 a.m.-5 p.m, closed for lunch 12p.m.-1p.m.

service_description: Assists transgender/gender non-conforming people in establishing Outside In as primary care location, initiate hormone therapy and manage their health as they physically transition. The ID Project helps change their legal documentation through the courts or DMV. Call for more information and appt. availability.
Food, mentoring, art, education, recreation and job training program for homeless young people ages 15-24.

REMOTE ONLY. Variety of services including compensation, education, insurance, loan guaranty, pension, and vocational rehabilitation and employment for veterans, service members, their families and survivors. www.benefits.va.gov/portland
Part of VA Portland Health Care System. Comprehensive medical and mental health services. In-patient services and emergency department.

Readjustment counseling services for combat veterans and their families, also for veterans who experienced military sexual trauma. Grief counseling for families who have lost someone in active service. Other services through VA, state and community agencies are also available
Part of VA Portland Health Care System. Services for veterans who are homeless or at risk of becoming homeless. Call to find out about medical care.
hours:
Walk-in hours: Tues. and Fri. 7:30-9 a.m.
Thurs. 10 a.m.-Noon.

service_description: Helps students 17-24 complete high school, hands-on job training in construction or technology. Enrolls year round. We offer two programs: YouthBuild For those ages 17-24 who want to finish high school and learn a trade.  Call 503-286-9350 Email apply@pybpdx.org.  Bridge For High School grads ages 18-26 who want to work in construction. Call 503-286-9350 x214. Email elle.goldstein@pybpdx.org.
LGBTQ+ focused health center. STI testing, PrEP, hormone therapy, HIV care, mental health services and primary care. Specialized services for transgender.

Provides safe spaces, community building and empowerment for the positive transformation of LGBTQ2SIA+ communities and allies in the region. Offers peer support groups, programs for LGBTQ+ seniors, drop-in hours and virtual events.
hours:
Hours: Mon. 12-4 p.m.
Tues.-Sat. 9:30 a.m.-5:30 p.m. 
Food pantry every 2nd and 4th Monday.

service_description: Provides support to parents in crisis, giving them time to get back on their feet while their children are cared for in a loving, safe environment by volunteer host families. Gives parents support and flexibility to work through challenges without fear of losing custody of their children. No cost to families. Also offers opportunities for mentoring and coaching of parents and teens. Call, check their website or get in touch: https://safefamiliespdx.org/get-in-touch. Serves tri-county area.

Per diem short-term transitional housing and case management for veterans. Up to ninemonth
program for vets and their families. Emergency transitional housing for singles only
up to 30 days with possible extension to 90 days max. VA must refer.

Phone enrollment only. Call and leave message with phone number for call back.
Parent support groups. Childcare provided. Call for updates.

parent_organization: Services and Advocacy for GLBT Elders (SAGE)
listing: Services and Advocacy for GLBT Elders
service_description: A program of Friendly House Senior Program. Works to enhance the lives of older (ages 60+) gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender community members through education, advocacy, outreach, resource referral. Call for a program schedule and events.

parent_organization: Sexual and Gender Minority Youth Resource Center
listing: Sexual and Gender Minority Youth Res. Ctr.
service_description: In person covid-conscious services. Drop-in center for Queer/Trans, LGBTQIA and questioning youths ages 13 to 23. Supportive social space, counseling, basic needs, resource referral, support groups, non-clinical gender affirmation, food boxes and community education. Support groups are virtual and in person, able to meet with youth one on one by appointment online. For additional information reference the website or instagram @SmyrcPDX.

LGBTQ+ youths ages 14-20. Drop-in, peer support, resource closet. Call or connect through Instagram (@thelivingroomyouth), For activities check Facebook; go to www.thelivingroomyouth.org for hours, location, call Call 503-825-2535 or email tlrinfo@newavenues.org
hours: Hours: Mon., Tues., Thurs. and Fri. 10a.m. - 6p.m.; Wednesday 10a.m.- 7 p.m.

service_description: Provides kindergarten readiness classes, after-school classes, parenting education, prevention, intervention, early learning programs, middle school programs, family engagement and resources for children throughout Clackamas County Schools. Call for info or check the website.

Outreach, support and housing with a faith-based approach. Housing for youths ages 18 to 24 (male and female) and pregnant or parenting females, ages 18 to 24. For more information visit transitionalyouth.org.
hours: Please see transitionalyouth.org for meal locations, days and times

service_description: Case management, short- and long-term housing programs. Eviction prevention, deposit assistance. Resources, referrals to VA, and other services. Supportive Services for Veteran Families (SSVF) program available. Services orientation available Tues. Screening and eligibility info - 1-855-425-5544 Orientation 9 a.m. Tues. at 650 NW Irving St. (Bud Clark Commons).
Connects veterans in crisis, their families and friends with VA responders. Press 1 for veterans or text 838255 or chat online.

listing: Washington County Disability, Aging & Veteran Services
service_description:
Programs and services to enhance quality of life and ensure basic needs are met for Wash.Co. seniors, veterans and people with disabilities. Most programs serve those 60 an older,but veterans and benefits enrollment center serves all ages. Includes Oregon Project Independence, food and nutrition services.

In-person services temporarily suspended; phone services only

listing: Washington County Transition Age Youth Intensive Services
service_description: Intensive Services Array program provides care coordination and wraparound mental health services planning for eligible older adolescents and young adults. Services may include community-based treatment, day treatment, treatment for foster care youths, respite, and psychiatric residential treatment. Access to services: Both services are provided by Lifeworks NW. TAYIS is in Tigard, Oregon, and can be accessed by calling 503-645-9010. EASA is in Beaverton, Oregon, and can be accessed by calling 503-705-9999.f you are on the Oregon Health Plan, other services may be available. Please contact your Coordinated Care Organization or visit our OHP page for links.
Serves children and families in the North Clackamas School District. Food pantry, clothes closet for students K-12, school supplies, hygiene supplies, dental health solutions.

Provides services that assist veterans who are homeless or at risk of becoming homeless. We provide veterans with the tools they need to gain new skill sets such as financial literacy, computer training, job search training, and interview guidance. Veterans learn skills to retain employment and become financially independent. Call for more information or apply for services online at www.or.easterseals.com
